choices.text: Reassure and advice regular follow up once in 6 months

questions.text: A 62-year-old female achieved menopause with smooth transition. She is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain. On examination, a right adnexal mass was palpable and non-tender. On ultrasound, a 3 X 3 cm cyst in her ovary was noted. What is the next best step?

choices.text: Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the treatment of recurrent ovarian cancer?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Platinum sensitive if recurrence > 6 months

questions.text: A mother of a 2-month-old infant is concerned about her baby's slow weight gain. The baby is exclusively breastfed. The baby passes urine 6-8 times a day. What is the most likely explanation in this case?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Insufficient intake of hindmilk

choices.text: Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year
Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sign indicating adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 3 kg?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year

questions.text: Identify the grip in the image given below:

A 5-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to hypothermia and poor feeding. The infant was cool to the touch this morning and would not wake to breastfeed. He was born via spontaneous normal vaginal delivery. The infant had an uncomplicated nursery stay and was discharged home at age 3 days. The patient's 3-year-old brother attends daycare and has had rhinorrhea and cough this week. Temperature is 35.1 C° (95.2 F°). Physical examination shows a hypotonic, lethargic infant with a full anterior fontanelle. Initial laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 2,000/mm with 20% bands. During the evaluation, the infant becomes apneic and requires intubation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this infant's condition?
All of the following markers are increased in preclampsia except:

choices.text: A 35-year-old woman who has undergone TAH+BSO
A 9-year-old girl who has Turner syndrome
A 47-year-old woman with hot flushes and history of breast cancer
A 60-year-old woman with a history of ischemic heart disease

questions.text: HRT should be prescribed to which of the following patients?
questions.solution: Ans. A) A 35-year-old woman who has undergone TAH+BSO

questions.text:
Anthropometric measurements for a 1-year-old child and corresponding values at birth are given below. Which of the following parameters indicates abnormal growth? 

 

  1. Weight - 6 kg; Birth weight - 3 kg
  2. Length - 75 cm; Birth length - 50 cm
  3. Head circumference (HC) - 47 cm; Birth HC - 34 cm
  4. Chest circumference (CC) - 47 cm; Birth CC - 31 cm

choices.text: Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3, High Inhibin-A
High MSAFP, low hCG, high UE3, Low Inhibin-A
Low MSAFP, high hCG, high UE3, High Inhibin-A
High MSAFP, low hCG, low UE3, Low Inhibin-A

questions.text: A pregnant woman has a fetus with Down's syndrome. Quadruple test done at 15-16 weeks will have:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3, High Inhibin-A

choices.text: Granulosa cell tumor
Embryonal cell tumor

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Embryonal cell tumor

 

 

Image 1 → Dysgerminoma:

 

  • Microscopy: Sheets of uniform round cells with clear cytoplasm, central nuclei (“fried-egg appearance”), fibrous septa infiltrated by lymphocytes.
  • Analogous to: Seminoma of testis.
  • Marker: ↑ LDH, PLAP.
     Diagnosis: Dysgerminoma.

 

Image 2 → Granulosa cell tumor:

 

  • Microscopy: Superfical cells seen on Pap smear indicating Estrogen production by GCT. 

 

Image 3 → Teratoma:

 

  • Microscopy: Contains mature elements from multiple germ layers—skin, hair follicles, sebaceous glands, etc.
  • Grossly: May show “dermoid cyst” with hair and teeth.Diagnosis: Mature cystic teratoma.

 

Image 4 → (Incorrectly labeled as Embryonal cell tumor):

 

It actually shows biphasic trophoblastic proliferation — cytotrophoblasts (clear cells) and syncytiotrophoblasts (multinucleated, eosinophilic cells) surrounding hemorrhage and necrosis.

 

This is characteristic of Choriocarcinoma — a malignant germ cell tumor of trophoblastic origin, not embryonal cell tumor.

 

Note: Embryonal cell carcinoma histology shows primitive, anaplastic cells arranged in various architectural patterns like solid sheets, tubular/glandular structures, or papillary formations. Key features include large, pleomorphic cells with abundant cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and a high rate of mitotic activity.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movement of limbs towards the body. On examination, there is a regression of developmental milestones. Electroencephalogram is shown below. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition?

A 32-year-old woman presents to AIIMS OPD with complaints of amenorrhea for the past six months. She has a history of two previous pregnancies, both of which resulted in miscarriages followed by dilation and curettage procedure after her last miscarriage. Physical examination reveals a normal BMI. She has a past history of pulmonary TB for which she completed ATT.  She underwent a HSG which is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

An 18-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to primary amenorrhea. The patient had ambiguous external genitalia noted at birth, and laparotomy performed at 17 months of age revealed a normal uterus and fallopian tubes. Ovarian biopsy performed at that time revealed normal-appearing primordial follicles. Blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg and height is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in). The patient has nodulocystic acne over the chest and back. No breast development, normal pubic and axillary hair, and marked clitoromegaly are present. Laboratory results show a normal female karyotype and normal glucose and serum electrolytes. Serum FSH, LH, testosterone, and androstenedione concentrations are high. Pelvic imaging reveals multiple ovarian cysts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A newborn infant presents with micrognathia with reduced mandibular body, relatively normal ramus, glossoptosis, and cleft palate. What is the diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman undergoes in vitro fertilization (IVF) and Embryo transfer is performed after the third day of fertilization. Based on this information, what is the estimated date of delivery (EDD) from the date of embryo transfer?

27-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 40 weeks gestation comes to the hospital due to painful contractions for the past few hours. The patient has had no leakage of fluid or vaginal bleeding. Fetal movement has been normal. On admission, the cervix is 5 cm dilated and 90% effaced with the fetal head at -1 station. She received epidural analgesia; on repeat cervical examination, the cervix is 6 cm dilated and 100% effaced with the fetal head at -1 station. Two hours later, the cervix is unchanged. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows a baseline of 130/min, moderate variability, accelerations, and occasional early decelerations. The tocodynamometer shows contractions every 5-7 minutes. Which of the following is the best next step is management of this patient?

A 6-month-old boy is brought to the OPD for follow-up after a urinary tract infection. The boy was initially brought in 2 weeks ago with fever for 4 days. The fever resolved within 48 hours with antibiotic therapy, and a full course of antibiotics was completed. Renal ultrasound performed 2 days ago showed mild right hydronephrosis. MCU is shown below. If untreated, which of the following is the most likely long-term complication of this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Fibrosis of renal interstitial space

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with swelling of the feet, apathy, and a protuberant abdomen. Examination is shown. Which of the following findings is least likely to be present in this child?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Loss of subcutaneous fat

questions.solution: Ans. D) Wait for spontaneous onset of labor

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension came with post-menopausal bleeding. Which of the following you will do to evaluate the cause?

The amniotic fluid was clear. The infant cries immediately and is actively moving all 4 extremities. He is taken to a warmer area and dried with blankets. A minute after delivery, heart rate is 120/min. He grimaces and cries vigorously during brief manipulation and examination by the provider. His body is pink but extremities are cyanotic. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Place on mother's chest

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 26 weeks gestation comes to the emergency department due to intermittent leakage of fluid for the past 6 hours. She has had no vaginal bleeding or contractions. The patient's previous pregnancy was complicated by preterm prelabor rupture of membranes at 29 weeks gestation; she delivered at 34 weeks gestation after inpatient management with corticosteroids and latency antibiotics. Temperature is 39.4° C (103° F), blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, and pulse is 114/min. Fetal heart rate is 170/min. The cervix is 2cm dilated. questions.text: A 3-week-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to lethargy. The patient was breastfeeding well until this morning when she became increasingly difficult to rouse. She was born at term to a 35-year-old woman who had a spontaneous vaginal delivery at home. The patient did not receive any vaccinations or medications after birth due to parental preference. Head circumference is at the 99th percentile. Weight and length are at the 25th percentile. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). Physical examination shows a large, bulging anterior fontanelle. The eyes are driven downward, and the patient does not appear to be able to look upward. No scalp swelling is present. lntracranial hemorrhage is confirmed on CT scan of the head. The patient's mother, gravida 1 para 1, has blood type A positive, and prenatal laboratory results and ultrasound were normal. Birth weight was 3.4 kg and length was 48.5 cm. He has been exclusively breastfed since birth and nurses for 10 minutes on each breast every 4 hours. He has 2 wet diapers each day but has not voided today. questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn presents with respiratory distress and abdominal distension. A nasogastric tube was inserted, and an X-ray was performed as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, and shortness of breath. She reports having a molar pregnancy that was treated and resolved a few months ago. She initially had a complete molar pregnancy with dilation and curettage (D&C) performed to remove the abnormal tissue. Her human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) levels were monitored and found to be persistenly elevated. On examination, she appears pale and distressed. Her vital signs show tachycardia and tachypnea. Pelvic ultrasound reveals multiple, irregularly shaped masses in the uterus. HRCT is shown. What is the stage of her disease?
What is the most common cause of Under-5 mortality in India?
Which of the following is a criterion for classifying the condition as complicated vesicovaginal fistula?
You can manage this case surgically by all of the following surgical procedures, except:

choices.text: Dandy Walker malformation

questions.text: Identify the correct pair of malformations:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dandy Walker malformation

 

 

The ultrasound images show posterior fossa abnormality — a large cystic space posteriorly that communicates with the fourth ventricle, along with elevated tentorium and cerebellar hypoplasia.

 

These are classic features of Dandy–Walker malformation (DWM).

 

Key Sonographic Features of Dandy–Walker Malformation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acrania: The image shows a fetal ultrasound with a "lemon sign." Typical frontal 'pinching' of calvarium gives a 'lemon' appearance of the skull, This is a tell tale signs of a shallow posterior fossa anomalies or Chiari malformation.

 

Option B. Holoprosencephaly: The image is a fetal ultrasound showing a cystic hygroma, which is a congenital lymphatic malformation. The red arrow points to the fluid-filled sac, which is typically found in the neck or head region of a fetus.

 

Option D. Omphalocele: The image is an ultrasound showing a fetus with gastroschisis. In this birth defect, baby's intestines and abdominal organs protrude through a para umbilical outpouching. The exposed organs are not covered by a protective membrane and float in the amniotic fluid, which can cause irritation and swelling. On the other hand, Omphalocele is a birth defect in which an infant's intestine or other abdominal organs protrude through the umbilicus and are covered by a thin sac.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with a body weight of 15kg and height of 100cm is admitted with renal failure. His blood urea was 100 mg/dL and serum creatinine was 1 mg/dL. What is the closest calculated eGFR in the patient?

The intern places a Foley catheter to fill up the bladder with 500 mL of saline and then clamps it. This method of relief of pressure on the cord is known as:

choices.text: The shortest AP diameter of the pelvic inlet is the obstetric conjugate.
Diagonal conjugate is measured from tip of sacral promontory to the lower margin of pubic symphysis.
Obstetric conjugate is calculated by subtracting 1.5 cm from diagonal conjugate.
Contracted pelvis is defined as transverse diameter <10cm and AP diameter <12cm.

questions.text: All of the following are true except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Contracted pelvis is defined as transverse diameter <10 cm and AP diameter <12 cm

questions.text:
A child is brought to the casualty with a history of choking. CXR is shown below. What would be the correct management? 

 

 

  1. Rigid Bronchoscopy
  2. Computed tomography scan
  3. ICD insertion
  4. UGIE

choices.text: Radical vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection
Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection

questions.text: A 76-year-old female presented with a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora midline for a period of 6 months, measuring 2 cm x 3 cm. No lymph nodes were palpable. Biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. How do you manage this case?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection

questions.text: In which of the following stages of puberty does estrogen not have a major role?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pubarche

 

  • Puberty is the sequence of events leading to sexual maturation and reproductive capability, regulated by activation of the hypothalamic–pituitary–gonadal (HPG) axis.
  • Different hormones dominate at different stages of pubertal development.
  • Pubarche results from adrenarche — increased secretion of adrenal androgens (DHEA, DHEAS, androstenedione) from the zona reticularis of adrenal cortex. Responsible for pubic and axillary hair growth, body odor, and mild acne.
  • Estrogen does not play a major role here.
  • Estrogen dominates in thelarche, menarche, and growth spurt (through its skeletal and endometrial effects).

 

Stages of Puberty and Their Hormonal Control:

choices.text: Used for entrapped aftercoming of head of breech

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Duhrssen’s incision?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Used for entrapped aftercoming of head of breech

questions.text:
An unconscious child is brought to the casualty. What is the correct sequence of the management? 

 

  1. Assess breathing
  2. Assess pulse
  3. Assess response
  4. Start compressions
  5. Bag and mask ventilation

A young female has history of a spontaneous abortion. She has had amenorrhea since then. Her FSH now is 6 mlU/ml. Which of the following can be a cause for her amenorrhea?

An investigator is studying the relationship between fetal blood oxygen saturation and intrauterine growth restriction using MRI studies. The magnetic resonance transverse relaxation time (T2) is inversely related to the concentration of deoxyhemoglobin so that high concentrations of deoxyhemoglobin produce a low signal intensity on T2-weighted MRI. In a normal fetus, the T2 signal is most likely to be the highest in which of the following vessels?
A 2-year-old child with delayed developmental milestones presents to the OPD. A T2 weighted MRI is performed, and the imaging result is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of nausea, increased urinary frequency, and breast tenderness. She has never had a menstrual period. She is actively involved in her school's volleyball team. She is 173 cm tall and weighs 54 kg; BMI is 18 kg/m2. Her breast and pubic hair development are at Tanner stage 5. Which of the following serum assays is the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Human chorionic gonadotropin

 

  • This patient has primary amenorrhea with fully developed secondary sexual characteristics (Tanner stage 5 breasts and pubic hair). 
  • She now presents with symptoms of early pregnancy — nausea, urinary frequency, and breast tenderness.

 

Key diagnostic clue:

 

  • A sexually active adolescent girl with amenorrhea and pregnancy symptoms → rule out pregnancy first, regardless of menstrual history.
  • Hence, the first and most appropriate test is serum or urine β-hCG to confirm or exclude pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estriol: Estriol is an estrogen measured to assess fetal well-being during pregnancy (e.g., in triple test). Not useful in evaluating amenorrhea or confirming pregnancy.

 

Option B. TSH: Thyroid dysfunction (especially hypothyroidism) can cause menstrual irregularities, but only after pregnancy is ruled out. It is a secondary test, not the first step.

 

Option D. Luteinizing hormone (LH): Measured to evaluate causes of primary amenorrhea like gonadal dysgenesis or hypothalamic dysfunction. However, this patient already shows full sexual maturation and pregnancy-like symptoms, so LH testing is premature until pregnancy is excluded.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has HSIL on Pap smear. What would be the management?

26-year-old female presented with mild pain in lower abdomen. She has had 2 full-term normal deliveries earlier. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks back. On pelvic examination, you find a palpable mass in the adnexa. USG pelvis is shown here. What is the next step?

choices.text: Five rotations in the same direction

questions.text: What is correct about the instrument shown here?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Five rotations in the same direction

questions.text: A pregnant woman has gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and her blood glucose levels are well controlled on insulin. What will be the appropriate gestational age for her delivery?

27-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 28 weeks gestation comes to the office for follow-up of an abnormal Pap test. The Pap test showed a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?

choices.text: Exposure to child with a rash
Lack of Rh(D) immunization in prior pregnancy

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, G2P0A1, at 26 weeks gestation comes to the OPD for an initial prenatal visit. Maternal blood type is O, Rh negative. Indirect Coombs test is negative. Abdominal circumference measures at 34 weeks gestation. USG is show below. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to this fetal presentation?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Exposure to child with a rash

questions.text: A lady with 7 weeks amenorrhea presented with slight vaginal spotting. Crown Rump Length was 5 mm with a well-formed gestational sac. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Repeat TVS after one week

questions.text: What is the next appropriate management in uterine inversion with partially removed placenta?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Manual repositioning of the uterus
